results.abstract: shuttle's crew is poised to continue build

headline.main: Shuttle's Crew Is Poised to Continue Building of Space Station

results.snippet: If the next space shuttle mission to the International Space Station seems familiar, that's because it is. Next week's planned voyage of the shuttle Endeavour is almost a mirror image of an October mission that added a large support beam to the...
results.lead_paragraph: If the next space shuttle mission to the International Space Station seems familiar, that's because it is. Next week's planned voyage of the shuttle Endeavour is almost a mirror image of an October mission that added a large support beam to the station. The Endeavour, carrying seven American and Russian astronauts, is scheduled to blast off on Monday morning from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on an 11-day mission. The shuttle will carry another 28,000-pound truss segment to expand the space station and a new crew of three to take over operations at the station for the next four months.

results.abstract: Brief profiles of six people with postgraduate degrees who have excelled in variety of professions; photos (special section, Education Life) (M)
results.snippet: The scholar's career path does not necessarily lead to academia. Take David Duchovny, who was sidetracked by the acting bug and never completed his dissertation at Yale, ''Magic and Technology in Contemporary American Fiction and Poetry.'' In fact,...
results.lead_paragraph: The scholar's career path does not necessarily lead to academia. Take David Duchovny, who was sidetracked by the acting bug and never completed his dissertation at Yale, ''Magic and Technology in Contemporary American Fiction and Poetry.'' In fact, he would fib about the extent of his schooling, ''for the silly reason that people would become intimidated by a worthless pedigree and diploma,'' Mr. Duchovny said back when his ''X-Files'' character, Fox Mulder, made him a star. Mr. Duchovny may be the most overeducated actor in Hollywood, but lots of unlikely Ph.D.'s have found success in the real world. Jack T. Ramsay After 11 years coaching at his alma mater, St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia, and a pro coaching record that led to induction in the Basketball Hall of Fame, Dr. Ramsay thought his doctorate in education would ease his way into administration as a dean or even a college president. But while his career on the bench ended with the Indiana Pacers in 1988, he has yet to leave courtside and now spins N.B.A. analysis for ESPN. Dr. Ramsay thinks his research for his Ph.D., awarded in 1963 by the University of Pennsylvania, proved an assist in making him a better coach. His dissertation found that, with few exceptions, students recruited by St. Joseph's for athletic ability developed into more well-rounded individuals and rose to the academic level of the student body. The study also deepened his appreciation of coaching. ''Coaching is the embodiment of everything -- physical, psychological, creative, competitive,'' he says. ''To put your team up against those with more talent, to keep your poise when everything is turning to ashes. It's very all-absorbing.''

results.abstract: Modern investigators, most with advanced gear, are probing ocean depths for wide range of lost items, with finds ranging from significant to silly; are finding that icy deep can preserve objects much longer than they would last on land; photos (M)1

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Lost and Found Dept.; Deep-Sixed Isn't Deep Enough

results.snippet: THE sunless depths aren't what they used to be. Once, if an item was tossed overboard, or a ship lost at sea, that was the end of it. Something ''deep-sixed'' was, by definition, irretrievable. ''Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean,'' Byron wrote....
results.lead_paragraph: THE sunless depths aren't what they used to be. Once, if an item was tossed overboard, or a ship lost at sea, that was the end of it. Something ''deep-sixed'' was, by definition, irretrievable. ''Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean,'' Byron wrote. ''Man marks the earth with ruin -- his control stops with the shore.'' No more. Modern investigators, most with advanced gear, are probing the depths for vanished gold and astronaut capsules, Nazi cargo and the lost city of Atlantis. Their finds range from significant to silly.

results.abstract: Family Fare column of upcoming events for children and families in New York area; photo (M)
results.snippet: An Enchanting Exhibition      You don't have to enroll at the Hogwarts school (or even buy a ticket to ''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets'') to experience the fun of being a sorcerer's apprentice. These days the Brooklyn Children's Museum is...
results.lead_paragraph: An Enchanting Exhibition You don't have to enroll at the Hogwarts school (or even buy a ticket to ''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets'') to experience the fun of being a sorcerer's apprentice. These days the Brooklyn Children's Museum is providing the flowing capes, the wands and lots of instruction. Best of all, the magic is real.

results.snippet: Over the last half-century, The New York Times Book Review's annual listing of the year's best illustrated children's books has included so many key titles by leading artists that retrospectively it offers a kind of pictorial guide to modern American...
results.lead_paragraph: Over the last half-century, The New York Times Book Review's annual listing of the year's best illustrated children's books has included so many key titles by leading artists that retrospectively it offers a kind of pictorial guide to modern American childhood. The first special children's books issue appeared in the fall of 1947. In 1952, just after the first baby boomers went off to kindergarten, the Book Review convened a special art jury -- representatives of the education departments of the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum, and the art department of the paper -- to look at 100 books culled from some 500 published that year. The jury chose and ranked seven, beginning with ''The Magic Currant Bun,'' by André François, and ending with ''A Hole Is to Dig,'' illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Ranked No. 5 was ''The Animal Fair,'' by Alice and Martin Provensen.

results.abstract: Sheryl Gay Stolberg article on three-year federal financed study on safety and effectiveness of methylphenidate (Ritalin) on preschoolers with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; focuses 4-year-old boy from suburban Connecticut who is participating in study; Steven Hyman, former director of National Institute of Mental Health, defends study, perhaps most controversial medical experiment ever conducted in children by federal government, on ground that so many preschoolers are already on drug even though it is not approved for children under age 6; photos (L)
results.snippet: On a warm, breezy Friday in September, a parade of mothers in minivans arrived at a preschool in suburban Connecticut to drop off a collection of 4-year-olds. Among the young students was Sam G., a sturdy, big-eared boy with cheeks that flush easily...
results.lead_paragraph: On a warm, breezy Friday in September, a parade of mothers in minivans arrived at a preschool in suburban Connecticut to drop off a collection of 4-year-olds. Among the young students was Sam G., a sturdy, big-eared boy with cheeks that flush easily and a personality that has earned him a reputation, politely speaking, as a handful. Like most 4-year-old boys, Sam loves things that move -- trains, planes and trucks, especially fire trucks -- and is usually on the move himself. When he enters a room, his clear blue eyes dart about, as though he cannot take in the sights fast enough. His knees and elbows are perpetually scraped. When his teachers read stories aloud, Sam often wanders about.

results.abstract: John Rockwell article on Steven Soderbergh's film Solaris, based on Stanislaw Lem's 1961 novel and Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky's 1972 film, both also called Solaris; new film stars George Clooney and Natascha McElhone; photos (M)

headline.main: On an Odyssey To Love's Outer Limit

results.snippet: CAN a mystery about the impossibility of alien contact become a great human love story? Steven Soderbergh thinks so.    On Wednesday ''Solaris,'' a major new film by the director of hits like ''Erin Brockovich'' and ''Traffic,'' will open nationwide....
results.lead_paragraph: CAN a mystery about the impossibility of alien contact become a great human love story? Steven Soderbergh thinks so. On Wednesday ''Solaris,'' a major new film by the director of hits like ''Erin Brockovich'' and ''Traffic,'' will open nationwide. Mr. Soderbergh not only directed it but also wrote it (and, without credit, oversaw the cinematography and the editing). So this film represents a considerable artistic investment for him -- not to speak of the financial investment by Fox International and James Cameron's Lightstorm Entertainment. They put up $47 million, which doesn't include the marketing costs.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour streaks into orbit on mission to deliver fresh team of astronauts and another 14-ton frame to International Space Station (S)

headline.main: Repaired Endeavour Takes Off With New Crew for Space Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour streaked into orbit this evening on a mission to deliver a fresh team of astronauts and another 14-ton frame to the International Space Station.    The launching came after two weeks of delays caused by an oxygen leak...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour streaked into orbit this evening on a mission to deliver a fresh team of astronauts and another 14-ton frame to the International Space Station. The launching came after two weeks of delays caused by an oxygen leak inside Endeavour, a dent in the shuttle robotic arm, and finally by bad weather at emergency landing strips in Spain.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students will pose scientific questions about food items and research their explanations. They will then create "recipe cards" with the answers and present their findings in a cooking show format.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students will pose scientific questions about food items and research their explanations. They will then create "recipe cards" with the answers and present their findings in a cooking show format.

byline.original: By PRISCILLA CHAN and BRIDGET ANDERSON

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
